DOCNAME: CASE OF ÇAMYAR AND BERKTAŞ v. TURKEY
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Art. 10;Violation of Art. 6-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Françoise Tulkens;Guido Raimondi;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Kristina Pardalos;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE . The first applicant is the owner of a publishing house in GPE which published a book giving rise to the present application . The second applicant is the editor and author of the book in question .

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor at ORG commenced an investigation in connection with a book , entitled PERSON , published and written by the first and second applicants respectively as a critique of the NORP penitentiary system . The book contains QUANTITY articles , CARDINAL of which are written by the second applicant , in which the authors criticise the cell system in NORP prisons . By way of examples from other countries and personal anecdotes , the second applicant claims in her articles that the cell system facilitates illtreatment and leads to deaths in prison . The introductory part of the book states the following :

“ This book is a salute to the new generations who fascism is trying to separate from our history of resistance and tradition of unity . It is a white page handed over by those who made courage and sacrifice the norm and created future revolutionary fighters . It is a message from those who , like a magnet , carried new powers from generation to generation to our ranks . We did not and will not allow [ future generations ] to forget the traditions and norms that were created during humanity 's , revolutionists ' and communists ' struggle and revolt against slavery , genocide , fascism and national and class exploitation ... In this book , we transmit our conscience and hearts to those who are fighting for a better future . ”

CARDINAL . The book also contains CARDINAL other articles written by persons serving prison sentences , following their conviction for having been involved in an illegal armed organisation called the PERSON ( ORG ) . In their articles , entitled “ Isolation cells are death cells ” , “ She was in [ prison ] , I was out ” , “ Empty the dungeons , free the prisoners ” and “ Prisons and health ” , the authors criticise the isolation of prisoners , ill - treatment of detainees and poor prison conditions and recount their personal experiences of imprisonment . Furthermore , the book comprises newspaper clippings concerning the real events on which the articles are based .

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor filed a bill of indictment against the applicants , accusing them of disseminating propaganda that undermined the territorial integrity and the indivisible unity of GPE through publishing , and of aiding and abetting an illegal armed organisation , namely , PERSON ( ORG ) , in certain parts of the book . The charges were brought under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL subsections CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE of PERSON no . ORG and Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the now defunct Criminal Code . The Government noted that PERSON ( ORG ) had been involved in a number of terrorist acts with a view to detaching part of the territory of GPE and forming a political regime based on ORG ideology . The organisation , which was qualified as a terrorist organisation under the domestic law of GPE , disseminated separatist propaganda within the NORP community and incited hatred and hostility by making distinctions on the basis of race and region .

CARDINAL . At the first hearing , held on DATE , ORG invited the applicants to present their defence arguments against the bill of indictment filed by the public prosecutor . Both applicants requested an extension of the time - limit for the preparation of their defence , which was granted . The applicants were informed that they were expected to present their defence arguments at the next hearing and that otherwise they would be deemed to have waived their defence rights in so far as the bill of indictment was concerned .

CARDINAL . At the second hearing , on DATE the applicants requested a further extension . The first applicant , PERSON , claimed that she had appointed a new lawyer who had prior engagements , and the second applicant argued that she had encountered problems in meeting with her lawyer due to the searches conducted on lawyers visiting the prison . ORG dismissed the applicants ' request for a further extension and indicated that that interim decision could be appealed against along with the decision on the merits .

CARDINAL . At the third and fourth hearings , on DATE and DATE PERSON requested extensions of the time - limit for submission of her defence arguments , whereas PERSON or her representative did not attend . The court granted the extensions requested and ruled that at the next hearing the applicants were required to be present and make their final submissions .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG heard the applicants ' defence submissions . The applicants pleaded not guilty and argued that in the book they had merely criticised fascist policies in GPE and , particularly , had expressed their opinion about the prison system . They claimed further that their trial by a ORG security court for publication of a book had constituted a violation of ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW . Following this hearing , ORG rendered its judgment and convicted the applicants under LAW of aiding and abetting the illegal armed organisation PERSON ( ORG ) . The court sentenced the first applicant to DATE and DATE imprisonment , convertible to a fine of MONEY ( TRL ) , and the second applicant to DATE , DATE and DATE imprisonment in view of her previous conviction of membership of the PERSON ( ORG ) . ORG did not make reference to any specific passages or pages of the book , but rather based its conviction on a review of the book as a whole .

CARDINAL . By petitions dated CARDINAL and DATE the applicants appealed against the above - mentioned judgment and requested ORG to hold a hearing . ORG decided to hold a hearing in respect of PERSON but dismissed the request of PERSON on the grounds that the conditions required under LAW had not been met .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of ORG without holding a hearing . It noted that PERSON and her representative had not attended the hearing and had not informed the court of the reason for their absence . The opinion of ORG submitted to ORG was not communicated to the applicants .
CARDINAL . On DATE the decision of ORG was returned to the registry of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants requested a re - examination of their case by ORG in view of the future entry into force of the new criminal code on DATE ( PERSON no . DATE ) . They further asked the court to suspend the execution of their sentences .

CARDINAL . In a judgment dated DATE ORG first determined which law was the most favourable in respect of the applicants . It held that the former criminal law was more favourable to the first applicant because she had been convicted of an offence under LAW and her sentence had been converted to a fine , whereas if the new amendments had applied she would have been sentenced to DATE of imprisonment , which could not be converted into a fine .

CARDINAL . As regards the second applicant , PERSON , the court held that the provisions of the new criminal code were more favourable to her . Thus , it convicted her of the offence under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . ORG . The court , after reducing the penalty to be imposed by CARDINAL under LAW , sentenced the second applicant to DATE imprisonment and to a fine of TRY CARDINAL . The applicants appealed .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date , ORG quashed the above judgment in respect of the first applicant , PERSON , on the ground that a pre - payment notice ( ön ödeme ihtaratı ) had not been served on her . It noted that the offence committed by the applicant fell within the scope of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . ORG , as amended by PERSON no . DATE , and that the said provision provided for a fine and required pre - payment .

CARDINAL . In a judgment dated DATE ORG convicted the first applicant , PERSON , of the offence under LAW and sentenced her to DATE and DATE imprisonment . ORG reiterated that the former criminal code was more favourable to the first applicant since it provided for a lighter sentence that could be converted to a fine . Thus , in the light of the new amendments , the court converted the first applicant 's prison sentence to a fine in the amount of TRY CARDINAL ( approximately EUR CARDINAL,CARDINAL ) . The court noted that the first applicant and her representative had failed to attend the hearing and had also failed to make the pre - payment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant appealed against that judgment . The proceedings are still pending before ORG .
CARDINAL . At the time of the applicants ' conviction , LAW provided as follows :

“ Any person who , knowing that an armed gang or organisation is illegal , assists it , harbours its members , provides it with food , weapons and ammunition or clothes or facilitates its operations in any manner whatsoever shall be sentenced to CARDINAL and DATE imprisonment ... ”
On DATE this Article was amended and the part “ ... or facilitates its operations in any manner whatsoever ... ” was deleted .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL of DATE ) , any person who disseminates propaganda in favour of a terrorist organisation shall be liable to a term of imprisonment of DATE .
